text: on March 15 2011 for New York Times
journalist covering a Libyan conflict
were captured near the front line by
Qaddafi government forces they were
blindfolded bound and taken to a
military base in Tripoli for two and a
half days their whereabouts were unknown
they were repeatedly beaten and
threatened with death their Libyan
driver is still missing despite efforts
to find him after six days the
journalists were released back in New
York
each sat down to reflect on what they
had learned about Colonel Qaddafi's
Libya in six days we didn't see one
Libya we saw three Libya's we started
out with the rebel forces and for most
of the time I was there they were a
rabble in retreat but they were adept at
propaganda they wanted the Western media
there and they knew what they wanted
from them they wanted to send out the
message that the West should impose a
no-fly zone they had a menu we want to
no fly zone but we don't want boots on
the ground they were very nervous about
having us there because the Gaddafi
forces were closed and then suddenly we
found out just how close those forces
were because we were captured by them we
were being dragged out of a car at
gunpoint at a checkpoint and these
people were punching and kicking and
groping our woman colleague and at the
same time we had the propaganda from
them equally expert Gaddafi's speeches
were ringtones on their cell phones and
they were assuring us that the rebels
were all al Qaeda and and the distresses
went on and then suddenly they put us in
a car and they drove us for eight hours
across the southern coast of the
Mediterranean any other circumstances it
would be a beautiful drive but we were
blindfolded and we were our hands were
bound and suddenly we found ourselves in
the third Libya in the heart of Colonel
Gaddafi's regime in marble floored
wood-paneled
ministry buildings with urbane diplomats
in perfect impeccable English assuring
us that we wouldn't be beaten assuring
us that they were a regime that they
should be taken seriously as such by the
international community they wanted
legitimacy and all the time we're
thinking yeah but on the far rim on the
outer spiral of your regime your edge of
control your men are beating and kicking
and punching and a rabble and it was a
very rare insight for Western
journalists into a country that few have
seen for decades now I've been covering
conflict since 2000
in the Middle East South Asia Africa and
I've been detained before in 2004 I was
detained in garma outside of Fallujah
and held for most of the day at gunpoint
with a colleague from the New York Times
and in that time I was never ever
mistreated I was not punched I was not
roughed around
I was not groped there were Sunni
insurgents and they treated me with
respect even though they were trying to
ascertain our identity in that time in
Libya it was incredibly surprising to me
how I was treated I have never been
punched in the face before this was the
first time in my life I've had a man
look me in the eye and punch me in the
face and especially when I was bound
hands and feet and at some point the
second time I was punched I was also
blindfolded so for me that was that was
astonishing it speaks volumes to me as
to what kind of society can have people
who treat women like this or who treat
international journalists like this what
does that say about the leadership of
Libya if journalists and women are
treated so abusively within seconds of
leaving a group of opposition fighters
we were captured by government soldiers
and in a flash you saw you're
transferred from one to the next and and
and you could see that the guys on the
other side of that hill were just as
poorly trained and and unable to make
decisions and without any order
whatsoever and this was this was quite
upsetting actually when we were caught
because at that time you want to be with
some Authority you want hierarchy you
want a commander to come along and say
these people are journalists these
people are under
they're not they're not to be treated
this way but that wasn't the case at all
there there were you know people running
all over the place you know threatening
to kill us in this one on for four for a
long time I thought there was a telling
moment when we arrived at the at the
airfield in Tripoli we were put into an
interior ministry vehicle we were
handcuffed and blindfolded and on the
tarmac there there was a fight between
the foreign ministry or what appeared to
be the foreign ministry the Defense
Ministry the interior ministry and
perhaps even brigades a little to
Muammar Qaddafi's son sons over who
would get us who would take control of
us and I thought it was a right there I
got the sense of what we were dealing
with this this this divide between the
semblance of a state are the pretensions
of a state and was really the wreckage
of a state I think we saw that wreckage
of the state from his da BIA all the way
to that tarmac in Tripoli where
government branches there in front of us
were fighting over who would take
custody of us I got the sense then that
this was not going to be Egypt this is
not going to be Tunisia it's not going
to be one of these Arab revolutions that
reach fruition rather quickly that
entered a transition and that a lot of
most of the people who took part in it
thought was going to go rather well this
was much darker incarnation of that
there is going to be a reckoning in
Libya that's going to last a long time
over how to confront four decades of
Muammar Qaddafi's rule and the legacy of
that rule that rule has disfigured the
society its disfigured the state and the
task of coming to terms with that may
very well haunt a generation
